inlineContent.text: A constant character string representing the POSIX path indicating where to store the keychain.
An unsigned 32-bit integer representing the length of the buffer pointed to by
A pointer to the buffer containing the password which is used to protect the new keychain. The password must be in canonical UTF-8 encoding. Pass
A Boolean value representing whether to display a password dialog to the user. Set this value to
to display a password dialog or
are ignored, and a dialog for the user to enter a password is presented.
On return, a pointer to a keychain object. You must call the
function to release this object when you are finished using it.
This function creates an empty keychain. The
parameters are optional. If user interaction to create a keychain is posted, the newly-created keychain is automatically unlocked after creation.

The system ensures that a default keychain is created for the user at login, thus, in most cases, you do not need to call this function yourself. Users can create additional keychains, or change the default, by using the Keychain Access application. However, a missing default keychain is not recreated automatically, and you may receive an
error from other functions if a default keychain does not exist. In that case, you can use this function followed by
, to create a new default keychain. You can also call this function to create a private temporary keychain for your application’s use, in cases where no user interaction can occur.

abstract.text: Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An opaque type that identifies a keychain item’s access information.
An opaque type that represents a keychain.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A raw pointer for accessing untyped data.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
